commonMistakes.title: Celsius to Fahrenheit Conversion Common Mistakes
items: Forgetting to add 32 - Only multiplying by 9/5 will give incorrect results
Incorrect order of operations - Adding 32 first and then multiplying by 9/5 is incorrect
Using the wrong fraction - Using 2/3 instead of 9/5 is a common error
Rounding too early - Rounding intermediate results can lead to inaccuracies

infoCard.title: About Celsius and Fahrenheit Temperature Units
paragraphs: Celsius (Â°C) is widely used internationally. At standard atmospheric pressure, water freezes at 0Â°C and boils at 100Â°C.
Fahrenheit (Â°F) is primarily used in the United States. At standard atmospheric pressure, water freezes at 32Â°F and boils at 212Â°F.

items.question: What is the difference between Celsius and Fahrenheit?
items.answer: Celsius and Fahrenheit are two different temperature scales. Celsius is widely used internationally, while Fahrenheit is common in the United States. They have different zero and boiling points: water freezes at 0Â°C / 32Â°F and boils at 100Â°C / 212Â°F.

items.question: How can I quickly estimate the conversion between Celsius and Fahrenheit?
items.answer: A quick estimation trick is Celsius Ã— 2 + 30 â‰ˆ Fahrenheit. For example, 20Â°C â‰ˆ (20 Ã— 2) + 30 = 70Â°F (actual 68Â°F). This mental math is useful for everyday approximations.

items.question: At what temperature are Celsius and Fahrenheit equal?
items.answer: Celsius and Fahrenheit intersect at -40. In other words, -40Â°C equals -40Â°F. This is the point where both scales show the same numeric value.

items.question: Is Celsius temperature bad for you?
items.answer: Celsius is simply a measurement unit. What matters is the actual temperature. For instance, 37Â°C is normal body temperature, while 60Â°C on skin can cause burns.
